courses.description: This course Introduces the entering pharmacy students to the profession of pharmacy; introduces various pharmacy practice environments such as hospital pharmacy, industry, academic research and community pharmacy; explores the scope of pharmacy and examines the roles of pharmacists in our current healthcare system; introduces the concept of clinical pharmacy and pharmaceutical care.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Interpret the current situation of pharmacy practice and analyze the future trend of pharmacy development in Hong Kong

2. Examine different roles of pharmacists at various pharmacy settings and in the healthcare system in Hong Kong

courses.description: This course provides an understanding of the processes involved in organic chemical reactions of the importance of stereochemistry in drug action and drug development. The theory and basic operation techniques of volumetric and gravimetric analyses; ultraviolet, visible and infrared spectroscopy and thin layer chromatography systems will also be covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. illustrate basic mechanisms of organic chemical reactions

2. relate basic concepts in a variety of functional groups to their chemical reactivity

3. discuss the chemical basis for some useful synthetic routes/pathways

4. appreciate the importance of stereochemistry in chemical reactions

5. perform simple chemical analysis
courses.course_syllabus:
Overview: Pharmaceutical Chemistry and new drug development

Stereochemistry

Free radical chain reaction

Nucleophilic substitution reaction SN1 & SN2 reactions

Elimination reactions

Electrophilic addition reactions etc

2. In-class instant feedback

3. Email exchange

4. Focus groups’ meeting

5. Individual meeting with students

courses.description: This course covers the foundation knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology through studying biochemical and cellular processes of the human body. Emphasis will be placed on the metabolic pathways and their interrelationship. Gene regulation and expression, human genetic diseases, and recent biomedical advancements will also be discussed.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Glycolysis, gluconeogenesis and pentose phosphate pathway
• Tricarboxylic acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation
• Amino acids metabolism
• Lipids and lipid metabolism
• Integrative metabolism and vitamins
• Nucleotide metabolism
• Gene regulation in prokaryotes
• Gene regulation in eukaryotes
• Human diseases I and II
• Project Presentation
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
• In-class instant feedback
• Email exchange
• Focus groups’ meeting
• Individual meeting with students

courses.description: This course provides a system-based review of the structures and functions, normal as well as abnormal, of basic tissues, blood and immune system, musculoskeletal system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system and gastrointestinal system. Emphases will be placed on those structures and functions that are relevant to common drug actions, and those that are affected by common drugs.

Haematology and Immune System.
Physiology of Nerve and Muscle Cells.
Cardiovascular System.
Respiratory System.
Digestive System.

Staff-Student consultation meeting at the end of the course.

courses.description: This course provides a system-based review of the structures and functions, normal as well as abnormal, of urinary system, endocrine system, reproductive system and nervous system. Emphases will be placed on those structures and functions that are relevant to common drug actions, and those that are affected by common drugs.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of the course, students should be able to:
a) describe the basic anatomical features of the urinary, endocrine, reproductive and central nervous systems;
b) recall the basic physiological functions of the urinary, endocrine, reproductive and central nervous systems; and
c) apply their anatomical and physiological knowledge to explain the abnormal conditions of diseases found in these body systems.
courses.course_syllabus:
Urinary system
Endocrine system
Reproductive system
Central Nervious System
Sensory physiology

courses.description: This course provides students with an introduction to microbiology and infectious diseases. Attention is focused on fundamental aspects of bacterial, fungal, and viral pathogenesis, therapy, control and prevention of infectious diseases. It also includes the basics of hospital infection and control in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection in the workplace.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe the fundamental aspects of microbiology (including but not limited to): cell structure and classification of microorganisms, isolation of microorganism, susceptibility testing and mechanisms of resistance
2. Recognize and discuss the pathogenesis, clinical manifestations, epidemiology, treatment and prevention of infections caused by gram-positive and gram negative bacteria and other microorganisms
3. Discuss the role of pharmacists in management of infectious diseases and utilization of antimicrobial agents
4. To understand the basis of hospital infection and control, in preventing spread of infection and protecting oneself from infection at workplace.

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Inter-professional Learning for Medication Safety
courses.description: As future stakeholder of our society, CUHK students should have a global citizen mindset and have the ability to observe and find solutions for social problems locally and globally. It will focus on elderly's health and drug related problems locally and internationally as an inter-professional healthcare team for students to prepare for a rapidly changing health service environment in both clinical and community settings.
courses.learning_outcomes:
5 key deliverables are expected upon completion of the course.

- Students' awareness of their own role in a multidisciplinary team will be enhanced.

- Students' understanding toward inter-professional collaboration practice will be enhanced.

- Students' abilities to observe elders' needs will be enhanced.

- Students' understanding toward global citizenship, social accountability will be enhanced.

- Students' innovative and critical thinking abilities will be enhanced.

Our lectures and e-learning materials will address the common health condition of elders, interprofessional collaboration, and drugs management for elderly patients. Furthermore, there will be interactive patient and student interactive activities in our workshops. Elderly patients will be invited to share their health background and health challenges they encounter in clinical and community setting.

We will collect and share students' service experiences and course evaluation in academic conference such as CUHK’s Teaching and Learning Expo, and other local and oversea educational conference. All in all, the course is expected to be sustained by positive and enhanced teaching and learning outcomes.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Common Diseases among elderly population
2. Communication with elderly patients
3. Introduction of medication safety
4. Fundamental concept of inter-professional collaboration
5. Roles of each healthcare provider
6. Transition from acute care to home care
7. Local and overseas health system
courses.feedback_evaluation: Pre and post course Interprofessional Collaborative Copetencies Attainment Survey (ICCAS) and feeback survey.
courses.required_readings:
1. Baxter SK, Brumfitt SM. Professional differences in interprofessional working. Journal of Interprofessional Care. 2008; 22(3): 239-51. PMID:18569411

2. Suter, E., Arndt, J., Arthur, N., Parboosingh, J., Taylor, E., & Deutschlander, S. (2009). Role understanding and effective communication as core competencies for collaborative practice. Journal of Interprofessional Care, 23, 41-51. PMID:19142782

3. Hammick M, Olckers L, et al. (2009). Learning in interprofessional teams: AMEE Guide no 38 Medical Teacher. 2009; 31(1): 1-12. PMID:19253148
courses.recommended_readings:
1. Framework for Action on Interprofessional Education & Collaborative Practice. World Health Organization. <http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/70185/1/WHO_HRH_HPN_10.3_eng.pdf?ua=1> [assessed 5 October 2017]

2. Institute of Medicine Committee on the Health Professions Education Summit. Health Professions Education: A Bridge to Quality. Greiner AC, Knebel E, eds. 2003; National Academy Press, Washington DC.

3. Buring SM, Bhushan A, Broesesker A, Conway S, Duncan-Hewitt W, Hansen L and Westberg S. Interprofessional Education: Definitions, Student Competencies, and Guidelines for Implementation. America Journal of Pharmaceutical Education 2009;73(4) Article 59: 1-8.

4. Zwarenstein M, Reeves S and Perrier L, Effectiveness of pre-licensure Interprofessional education and post-licensure collaborative interventions. Journal of Interprofessional Care. 2005;19(Sup 1):148-165.

courses.description: This course introduces the principles of drug design and development of new therapeutic agents from semi- or wholly-synthetic prototype compounds, or from biologically active compounds derived from natural sources. Structure-activity relationships (SAR) and quantitative SAR in drug design/development will be discussed in detail. Special topics will include pro-drugs, enzyme inhibitors and drug metabolism.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand the general approach of rational drug design
2. Explain the chemical basis for some of the known mechanisms of drug action
3. Illustrate the role of molecular modification in the development of new drugs
4. Relate chemical structure to biological availability, biological activity and routes of delivery/metabolism for drugs from selected drug classes
courses.recommended_readings:
Textbook-
"Medicinal Chemistry: Fundamentals" Edited by Roland Barret (2018) Barret, Roland, ISBN 0815345569 CUHK UL - QV744.B277 2018
Electronic Resources –
"Medicinal chemistry self-assessment [electronic resource] / edited by Robin M. Zavod Bethesda, Maryland: ASHP Publications, 2015

courses.title: Pharmaceutical Analysis

meetings.instructor:
Professor NG Wai Lung, 
Professor TO Kin Wah
Professor TO Kin Wah
Professor TO Kin Wah

courses.description: This course examines the theory and application of analytical methods and spectroscopic/spectrometric techniques such as atomic emission (AE) and atomic absorption (AA), infrared (IR), ultraviolet (UV), fluorimetry, mass spectrometry and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR); separation methods such as high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and gas chromatography (GC); and special techniques such as immunochemistry for the analysis and structure elucidation of drugs.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Be able to Identify, characterize, and elucidate the structure of drug compounds by spectroscopic techniques such as infrared (IR), ultraviolet (UV), nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), and mass spectrometry (MS)
Be able to perform qualitative and quantitative analysis of pharmaceutical preparations by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), gas chromatography (GC), fluorimetry, atomic absorption, and immunoassays
Be able to perform and create standard drug assays
Be able to integrate appropriate laboratory classes with analytical concepts taught in lectures
courses.course_syllabus:
Simple Chemical Properties and Methods
Atomic Spectroscopy
Ultraviolet/Visible Spectroscopy
Infrared Spectroscopy
Spectrofluorimetry
Chromatography
Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
Mass Spectrometry
Immunoassays
Drug Standards and Drug Identification
courses.feedback_evaluation: End of term Course and Teaching Evaluation
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings:

3. Integrate laboratory practicals with theoretical concepts covered in lectures and to apply the principles to the design, formulation and quality control of solution dosage forms

courses.description: Examines the physico-chemical principles relevant to drug formulation and manufacturing; rheology; drug decomposition and accelerated stability tests. Emphasis will be on the formulation of emulsion and suspension dosage forms. Relevant topics in surface chemistry will be covered.

1. Acquire an understanding of the basic principles of surface chemistry

2. Acquire an understanding of the mechanism of formation and stabilization of emulsions and suspensions

3. Identify and solve common problems of physical instability associated with emulsion and suspension dosage forms

4. Acquire an understanding of chemical degradation and its application to expiry dating of pharmaceutical products

5. Integrate laboratory practicals with theoretical concepts covered in lectures and to apply the principles to the design, formulation and quality control of emulsion and suspension dosage forms

courses.description: This course provides an overview of the pharmaceutical dispensing practice as it relates to the interpretation and assessment of prescriptions and the formulation and preparation of medications for administration and use in patients. This course will emphasize the application of pharmaceutical calculation, the role of various dosage forms and their routes of administration, extemporaneous compounding, the preparation and handling of sterile products for parenteral use, and practical considerations in the dispensing of medications in different patient populations.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 1. Demonstrate understanding of the medication dispensing process and how various dosage forms can be appropriately used by patient
2. Discuss the examples of pharmaceutical formulations and their routes of administration
3. Demonstrate proficiency in pharmaceutical calculations in ensuring effective and safe use of medication during medication dispensing process
4. Describe the significance of sterile dosage form preparation, as well as the benefits and risk of aseptic techniques
5. Compare and contrast the properties and use of different materials, equipments, and facilities in sterile compounding
6. Demonstrate proficiency in using aseptic techniques for compounding sterile preparations including parenteral cytotoxic drugs and total parenteral nutrition products
7. Discuss the appropriate measures for handling medication and medical wastes in the compounding process
8. Describe the role of and show proficiency in extemporaneous compounding in optimizing patient outcomes
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Medical abbreviations and pharmaceutical calculations
2. Compounding techniques
3. Dosage forms of different physical states
4. Routes of administration
5. Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
6. Cytotoxic drugs
7. Sterile and non-sterile compounding
8. Requirements for prescription and dispensing label
9. Use of drug information resources in dispensing process
courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-Term Course and Teaching Evaluation
courses.required_readings: Watson J, Cogan L. Pharmacy Practice, 6th Edition. Elsevier 2020
courses.recommended_readings:
* Allen LV, McPherson TB. Ansel's Pharmaceutical Dosage Forms and Drug Delivery Systems, 12th Edition. Wolters Kluwer 2023
* Taylor KMG, Aulton ME. Aulton's Pharmaceutics, 6th Edition. Elsevier 2021

courses.description: Provides students with a working knowledge and the application of laws and regulations affecting pharmacy practice in Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes: To understand the function of the Pharmacy and Poisons Board of Hong Kong and the regulatory framework for the manufacture, registration, advertisement and distribution of pharmaceutical products, including antibiotics and dangerous drugs.
courses.course_syllabus: The Pharmacy and Poisons Board of Hong Kong; Legal Classification of Pharmaceutical Products & Dangerous Drugs; Control and supply of Antibiotics; Registration of Pharmaceutical Products and Substances; Manufacturing of Pharmaceutical Products; Listed Sellers of Poisons and Authorised Sellers of Poisons; Retail sale of Poisons; Supply and storage of medicine in institutions; Undesirable Medical Advertisements Ordinance; Wholesale of Poisons and Import/Export of Pharmaceutical Products; Sales and Supply of Dangerous Drugs; Import and Export of Dangerous Drugs etc

courses.description: This course introduces the concepts of contemporary pharmacy practice. Topics include interpretation and evaluation of different types of prescription, observation of legal requirements in dispensing, record keeping and storage of medicines, ethical dilemma in pharmacy practice, patient counselling techniques, medication adherence and disposal, evidence-based medicine in pharmacy practice, handling of drug information requests, use of common medical products and self-administration injectable medicines. Concepts in primary care and vaccination administration training is also provided in this course.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Communicate effectively with patients and health care providers
2. Display professional, ethical, and moral conduct in a pharmacy or professional setting
3. Evaluate prescriptions and dispense medicines in accordance to current pharmacy laws and with ethical behavior
4. Provide patient counseling and make recommendations based on common health screening results
5. Discuss the essential concepts related to practice in primary care setting
6. Demonstrate the knowledge and technical skills to provide vaccination to the general public
7. Identify and evaluate drug information resources and apply relevant knowledge and skills for handling drug information requests
8. Describe the factors that can influence medication adherence and the approaches that pharmacists can use to improve medication adherence
9. Describe the impact of medication wastage and inappropriate medications disposal, and the current practice/recommendation of medication disposal in different countries
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Drug information and evidence-based medicine
2. Communication with patients and healthcare providers
3. Dispensing practice
4. Primary care
5. Vaccination
6. Medication adherence and disposal
7. Use of health-related devices, self-administration injectable medications, and inhalers

courses.description: This course provides students with an understanding of the principles of drug action including pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics. The pharmacotherapy of disorders associated with various organ systems are discussed in a modular system over four terms. In each module, the general pathology together with the clinical features, diagnostic and monitoring parameters of the therapy are to be introduced. The course will provide the student with an understanding of the mechanisms of action, pharmacological effects, clinical indications and relevant side effects of the most important drugs used. The modules of diseases/drugs covered include central nervous system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, gastrointestinal system, immunological system, endocrine system, chemotherapy and others. Pharmacoeconomic analysis and its role in pharmacotherapy will also be discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To recognize the clinical manifestations of disease
To counsel patient on the use of drug therapy
To recommend appropriate treatment considering patient-related and drug-related factors
To monitor the efficacy and safety of drug therapy
To explain the rationale of drug therapies in terms of the mechanisms of actions and side effect profiles of drugs
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
Basic mechanisms of drug action
Drug action on the peripheral nervous system
Autacoids and inflammation
Drugs and the gut
Thyroid Disorder
courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-Term Course and Teaching Evaluation
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers
courses.recommended_readings:
Rang and Dale’s Pharmacology by Ritter J. M., Flower R. Henderson G., Loke Y.K., MacEwan D., Robinson E., Fullerton J.: Elsevier, 10th Edition (2023)
Basic & Clinical Pharmacology by Katzung, B.G.: Lange Medical Publications, 15th Edition (2021). (available at Accesspharmacy online)
Pharmacotherapy: A Pathophysiologic Approach, 11th Edition (2020). (available at Accesspharmacy online)
Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition (2022). (available at Accesspharmacy online)

courses.description: This course introduces students to the use of medicinal plants in pharmacy practice. Topics include sources, chemistry and uses of phytochemical substances from plants including alkaloids, glycosides, terpenoids, carbohydrates, fixed and volatile oils; manufacture, quality control and regulation of medicinal herbal products.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Familiar with the metabolic pathways of plant, major phytochemical groups and major active components in commonly used herbs in practice.

• Understand the general classification of plant drugs, their sources and the factors affecting the cultivation, collection and preparation of crude plant drugs.

• Understand the general process of extraction, separation and isolation of phytochemicals and general process of manufacturing herbal extract based product.

• Familiar with the quality control approaches of herbal drugs and registration of pTCM in Hong Kong.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction of Natural Herbs

Natural Product Chemistry

Plant design: origin, process and evaluation

Manufacture of TCM in Hong Kong

Application of herbal medicine in pharmacy practice

Modernization of Chinese Medicine Practice in Hong Kong

Registration of herbal products and Proprietary Chinese Medicines in Hong Kong

courses.description: This course provides students with an understanding of the principles and methods of pharmaceutical research in pharmaceutical sciences and pharmacy practice. Topics include: the use of qualitative and quantitative research methods; research design; statistical analysis of different types of data; application of computer software for data analysis; clinical research, ethics and literature review; and application to research and practice.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To know the range of study design in drug development and clinical practice

To understand statistical concepts and techniques in study planning, design and data analyses

To apply appropriate statistical techniques and anlyses in hypothesis testing or decision making for problems in pharmaceutical research, pharmacy practice and drug development

To critically evaluate clinical research literature

To design, conduct, interpret, and report a simple study
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Data collection, presentation of data, descriptive statistics

2. Research planning, study design and research ethics

3. Inferential statistics; hypothesis testing

4. Statistical models: correlation and regression

5. Clinical research literature review

6. Selected topics in statistical techniques and applications

courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and principles of healthcare management and marketing relevant to pharmacy practice in various settings. The student will have opportunities to develop and design common management tools.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Apply basic principles of management and marketing in building effective professional relationships with customers (patients) and other health care professionals who have vested interest in safe and effective medicine.

- Describe the impact of pharmacy informatics and other health information technology on health care practice and medication safety.

- Implement drug use management and explain the application of cost-effective prescribing.

- Understand various management approaches and the importance of leadership and motivational skills.

- Understand differences in management between the difference pharmacy sectors.

(2) Business Communication

(3) Leadership, Motivation & Emotional Intelligence

(4) Marketing and Applications to Pharmaceutical Products

(5) Management in the Drug Office

(6) Management in Pharmaceutical Industry

(7) Medication Safety in Health Care & Pharmacovigilance

(8) Management in Community Pharmacy

(9) SWOT Analysis, Strategic & Business Planning

(10) Procurement Strategy, Staffing & Inventory Management

(11) Drug Use Management

(12) Pharmacy Informatics

(13) Management in a Hospital Authority Hospital

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Health System Management
courses.description: This course provides a general overview on the management of health care system. The student will learn about the organization of Hong Kong health care system, and how health economic outcomes and evidence based medicine are used to determine drug formulary or clinical guidelines in health care system. The course also will discuss the importance of medication safety and various strategies that are used to ensure medication safety including health policy implementation and the use of health information technology.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Describe basic pharmacy management principles within the Hong Kong health care system including formulary and inventory management, pharmacoeconomics, and pharmacovigilance.

• Understand the different drug distribution systems in Hong Kong.

• Discuss the concepts of pharmacy practice in the managed care setting.

• Describe drug use management and application of cost-effective prescribing.

• Understand the importance of medication safety and its application in practice.

• Describe the impact of pharmacy informatics and other health information technology on health care practice and medication safety.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Health Care system

- Drug Use management

- Quality and Safety

- Pharmacovigilance

- Pharmacy Informatics

courses.description: This course examines the role of community pharmacists. Topics include discussion of ethical principles and theories as they relate to pharmacy practice, differential recognition and recommendation of over-the-counter (OTC) products for common minor ailments, health promotion, patient education on contraceptives, smoking cessation and home testing products and examination of the role of the pharmacist in combating drug abuse.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Describe the pharmacist's role in the community pharmacy
Outline the various factors affecting patient's self-care decisions
Apply appropriate assessment skills and referral skills when responding to patients' symptoms
Offer appropriate advice and counsel patients on the selection and use of non-prescription products for the purpose of self-care
Provide information and advice on a number of health promotional issues, including contraception, smoking cessation and home testing products
Identify the ways in which the pharmacist can act as a gate-keeper in combating drug abuse
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction to Self-care Counseling
Responding to Symptoms in the Pharmacy
Health Promotion for Pharmacists
Substance Abuse

courses.description: This course provides students with an understanding of the principles of drug action including pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics. The pharmacotherapy of disorders associated with various organ systems are discussed in a modular system over four terms. In each module, the general pathology together with the clinical features, diagnostic and monitoring parameters of the therapy are to be introduced. The course will provide the student with an understanding of the mechanisms of action, pharmacological effects, clinical indications and relevant side effects of the most important drugs used. The modules of diseases/drugs covered include central nervous system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, gastrointestinal system, immunological system, endocrine system, chemotherapy and others. Pharmacoeconomic analysis and its role in pharmacotherapy will also be discussed.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To recognize the clinical manifestations of disease
To counsel patient on the use of drug therapy
To recommend appropriate treatment considering patient-related and drug-related factors patient on the use of drug therapy
To monitor the efficacy and safety of drug therapy
To explain the rationale of drug therapies in terms of the mechanisms of actions and side effect profiles of drugs
courses.course_syllabus:
Drug Action on the cardivascular system
Drugs affecting hormone system
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers
courses.recommended_readings:
Pharmacy Suggested Reading:
Pharmacotherapy: A Pathophysiologic Approach by DiPiro, J.T. et al: McGraw-Hill, 11th Edition (2020). (available at Accesspharmacy online)
Goodman & Gilman's: The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th Edition (2022). (available at Accesspharmacy online)
Pharmacology Suggested Reading:
1. Rang and Dale’s Pharmacology by Ritter J. M., Flower R. Henderson G., Loke Y.K., MacEwan D., Robinson E., Fullerton J.: Elsevier, 10th Edition (2023)
2. Basic & Clinical Pharmacology by Katzung, B.G., Trevor, Anthony J., Masters, Susan B.: Lange Medical Publications, 15th Edition (2021).

courses.description: This course provides an overview of the latest advancements in pharmaceutical biotechnology with an emphasis on therapeutics and diagnostics involving macromolecules, mainly proteins and oligonucleotides, as well as cell therapies. The basic principles of pharmacogenomics and its application in predicting drug responses and adverse drug reactions will also be covered.
courses.course_syllabus:
(1) Protein therapeutics (antibodies, hormones, and other proteins)
(2) Protein diagnosis
(3) Nucleic acid therapeutics (DNA and RNA as drugs)
(4) Pharmacogenomics (prevention of adverse drug reactions and dose optimization)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
(1) End-of-term Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
(2) Students will be asked to complete a brief score card for learning experience in each lecture (on a scale of 1-10; 10 – most satisfactory). Specific comments and concern can be put down on the card.
(3) Email exchange
(4) Individual meeting with students
courses.required_readings: Nil
courses.recommended_readings:
1. **Current Applications of Pharmaceutical Biotechnology** edited by Ana Catarina Silva, João Nuno Moreira, José Manuel Sousa Lobo, Hugo Almeida. Springer Nature Switzerland AG: Springer, 2020. (eBook ISBN: 9783030404642; University Library online access.)
2. **Biopharmaceuticals**. Edited by S.N. Jogdand. Mumbai [India]: Himalaya Pub. House, 2006. (ISBN 9788183186209; University Library online access.)
3. **Pharmacogenomics: an introduction and clinical perspective.** Edited by Joseph S. Bertino Jr, C. Lindsay DeVane, Uwe Fuhr, Angela D.M. Kashuba, Joseph D. Ma. New York: McGraw-Hill, 2013 (ISBN: 9780071741699; University Library online access.)
4. **The Pharmacogenomics Knowledge Base [PharmGKB]**. Integrated resource about how variation in human genetics leads to variation in response to drugs. (https://www.pharmgkb.org/)
5. **Genetics/Genomics Competency Center: G2C2**. Educational resources for self-directed learning in genetics/genomics by health care practitioners. (http://www.g-2-c-2.org)

courses.description: Introduces students to the application and evolution of alternative medicines. Focusing on different types of alternative medicines including dietary supplements, herbal medicine, traditional Chinese medicine, homeopathy and aromatherapy.
courses.learning_outcomes:
•be familiar with popular complementary and alternative medicines (CAM) and their intended use

•be able to list examples of CAM for specific indications

•know the active constituents, mechanism of action, clinical applications, side effects and contraindications of selected CAM

•be familiar with common interactions among, herbs, drugs, diseases and supplements

•be able to describe the roles of pharmacists in CAM

•be able to conduct evidence based research and evaluate the quality of complementary and alternative medicines for use in daily practice

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: International Pharmacy Practice
courses.description: This elective course offers students the opportunity to learn about pharmacy practice in overseas countries. Students participating in the course will gain a better understanding of the daily activities of a pharmacist at the host institution, differences between Hong Kong and overseas health care system and what it is like to be a pharmacist in another country.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Discuss the differences between local (Hong Kong) and international pharmacy practice
• Describe the roles and responsibilities of pharmacists in an overseas practice setting
• Consider opportunities and challenges encountered by overseas pharmacists and how it applies/ differs to Hong Kong
• Suggest ways to incorporate their experiences into their future practice
courses.course_syllabus:
• Community Pharmacy
• Ambulatory Care Pharmacy
• Hospital Pharmacy Practice
• Clinical Pharmacy
• Specialty Pharmacy Practice
• Research (Practice-Based)

courses.description: This course is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. It consists of one week of clerkship training completed in the summer term before the final year under the supervision of a community pharmacist. Students will gain knowledge and experience in the operational aspects of the pharmacy and participate in the professional services.

• Professional Conduct
• Patient Confidentiality

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Hospital Pharmacy Summer Clerkship

meetings.instructor: Dr. ZHOU Keary Rui

courses.description: This course is an elective clerkship consisting of one week clinical pharmacy clerkship training in the hospital setting. It is intended for students who choose research as an area of concentration in the final year. This clerkship provides an overview of the role and function of pharmacist in the hospital pharmacy practice setting. During the clerkship experience, students will participate in activities include ward rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, provision of drug information to patients and other healthcare providers, participation in the choice, dosing and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimize efficacy, safety and cost-effectiveness.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, the students will be able to:
• Outline the roles and responsibilities of a hospital pharmacist.
• Demonstrate ability to organize the work/tasks and complete assigned task on time.
• Demonstrate ability to collaborate with others.
• Acquire basic knowledge of some disease states such as hypertension, diabetes or asthma.
• Obtain mediation-related information from a MAR.
• Present a comprehensive patient case.
• Identify and appropriately utilize drug information resources to assist with patient-specific drug therapy monitoring.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to Hospital Pharmacy Clerkship
• SOAP presentation
• Professional Conduct
• Patient Confidentiality
• Patient Counseling
• Drug information
• Disease Management
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• End-of-term Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
• A questionnaire on evaluation of the clerkship site(s) and tutor(s).
courses.required_readings: N/A

Nemire RE, Kier KL. eds. Pharmacy Student Survival Guide, 2e. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill; 2009.

courses.description: PHAR 3812 is the preparatory course prior to the clinical clerkship or the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the internal medicine ward and to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Due to the nature of the clinical pharmacy clerkship, the preparatory course is designed to prepare students for the upcoming clinical pharmacy clerkship, as well as the final year Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE). The main targeted areas in PHAR 3812 include literature evaluation, drug information, clinical assessment & monitoring, patient data documentation, medical chart review, and role play of clinical scenarios.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Medical chart documentation
2. Professional communication skills
3. Literature evaluation
4. Basic concepts of fluid and nutrition
5. Drug information techniques
6. Mock OSCE experience

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Pharmacy Clerkship: Community-based Practice

meetings.instructor: Professor LEUNG Shui Yee

courses.description: This elective clerkship provides students with the opportunity to learn how pharmaceutical care is practiced in the community pharmacy settings. This course introduces students to a range of practice settings (e.g. independent pharmacies, non-government organization, etc.), each of which offers a unique perspective and opportunity to learn various skills in pharmacy practice.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the conclusion of the clerkship and completion of assigned duties and tasks, the students should be able to:
1. Describe the role of pharmacists and its impact on primary care in Hong Kong.
2. Identify key components needed to utilize and maximize medication safety
3. Provide drug education on prescription, non-prescription and complimentary alternative medicines.
4. Strengthen therapeutic knowledge of chronic disease states
5. Establish competent counseling and patient communication skills.
6. Counsel patients on common non-prescription items available in a community pharmacy setting.
7. Improve proficiency in communicating with future colleagues and other health care professionals.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to independent community pharmacy, NGO pharmacy practice.
• Professional conduct
• Patient confidentiality
• Pharmacy law and ethics
• Dispensing practice
• Patient counseling
• Responding to symptoms
• Bar code technology
• Electronic medication history and record

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Pharmacy Management and Adminstration Clerkship
courses.description: This course is an elective clerkship provides students with opportunity to learn about pharmacy operation management in a health care organization. Students will be able to gain understanding on the role of pharmacists in pharmacy practice management, drug use management, pharmacy personnel training, and technology planning.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, the students will be able to:
• Describe the role of Pharmacist within health care organization management team.
• Understand the medication management process in health care organizations.
• Demonstrate the understanding of pharmacy management and related administrative activities.
• Develop professional communication skills by formulating written and/or oral answers or review for drug information enquiries.
• Develop project management skills and demonstrate ability to organize assigned work/tasks efficiently & efficiently in meeting deadlines.
• Demonstrate ability to collaborate with others and sharing ideas at professional level.
courses.course_syllabus:
* Pharmacy operation and management
* Medication Management and Safety
* Drug information and Professional communication
courses.feedback_evaluation:
• End-of-term Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
• A questionnaire on evaluation of the clerkship site(s) and tutor(s).

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Hospital Pharmacy Clerkship

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LEE Chui Ping, 
Dr. TAI Bik Wai, 
Dr. YUEN Siu Hong Johnny, 
Dr. ZHOU Keary Rui, 
Professor LAM Tai Ning

courses.description: This is a three-week hospital practice rotation at a public or private hospital. The purpose of this rotation is to provide exposure to our fourth year undergraduate pharmacy students on pharmacy practice, pharmacy operation in the hospital setting and some clinical service(s), if available, outside the typical classroom. This will allow students to understand the role of a pharmacist in an in-patient environment. The preceptors would guide students’ learning by providing carious learning activities. Students are expected to be hardworking and dedicated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: PHAR3413 and PHAR3414 and PHAR3415 and PHAR3812.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the three-week rotation, the student should:
• Be able to understand the daily routine activities of a pharmacist in a hospital.
• Have a basic knowledge of some disease states such as hypertension, diabetes or asthma
• Be able to obtain medication-related information from a Medication Administration Record (MAR)
• Be able to present a comprehensive patient case
• Be able to identify and appropriately utilize drug information resources to assist with patient-specific drug therapy monitoring
• Be able to use a systematic approach to answer drug information query from other healthcare professionals;
• Be able to assess and determine the specific information and counseling required in each patient case.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Basic knowledge of some disease states such as hypertension, diabetes or asthma
• Basic technique and skills to handle drug information enquiries
• Introduction of hospital pharmacy service including the roles of pharmacy in drug distribution system and general operation workflow
• Understanding the drug formulary in the hospital including introduction on various committees relevant to pharmacy practice e.g. Drug Advisory Committee (DAC), Drug Therapeutics Committee (DTC) etc. and development of prescribing guidelines/policies
• Principles and workflow of addition/deletion of formulary drugs and sample drugs
• Clinical and communication skills in patient monitoring and counselling with practical cases illustration
courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-term Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)
courses.required_readings: N/A
courses.recommended_readings:

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Cardiology
courses.description: The clinical clerkship is a minimum of 3-week clerkship for the pharmacy students at the Prince of Wales Hospital. It allows pharmacy students to experience patient-focused pharmacy practice. The emphasis of this clerkship is to provide quality training to clerkship students in the cardiology ward. This will allow students to have more hand-on experience outside the typical classroom. Activities of the clerkship include daily pharmacy rounding, communication with other healthcare professionals, participation in the choice, dosing, and monitoring of drugs for individual patients to optimise efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness during daily case discussion with preceptor and the hospital pharmacy rotation. This is a higher level of training that requires higher expectations and levels of responsibility. As a student pharmacist in the clinical clerkship, you are expected to be hardworking and dedicated. You will be dealing with patient lives and some of the most prestigious cardiologists in Hong Kong.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- To understand usual inpatient patient presentation and management in cardiovascular diseases
- To gain clinical experience with therapy assessment and monitoring
- To gain experience in counseling patients who may benefit

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Oncology

meetings.instructor: Dr. ZHOU Keary Rui

courses.description: This course is an elective clerkship providing an introduction to the pharmacological management of various hematological malignanies, namely leukemia, lymphoma, multiple myeloma, and autologous stem cell transplant. Students will participate in ward rounds with hematology oncologists, as well as shadow in the hematology outpatient clinic. Students will learn about disease pathology, symptomology, diagnostic parameters, and drug monitoring parameters through patient case discussion. Other topics including oncology supportive care, antimicrobial prophylaxis, and pain control will also be covered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Describe the common treatment options for the various hematologic malignancies
• Understand the rationale of the use for the different supportive care medications
• Familiarize with the common adverse side effects of the drugs used in this specialty
• Analyze a patient case and identify any drug-related problem and be able to formulate a plan to optimize therapy
courses.course_syllabus:
Hematologic malignancies
o Leukemias
o Hodgkin’s lymphoma
o Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
o Multiple myeloma
o Autologous Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation
Chemotherapy regimens
Supportive care
Empiric use of antimicrobial agents in neutropenic fever

courses.title: Hospital Pharmacy Experience in Mainland China

meetings.instructor: Dr. ZHOU Keary Rui

courses.description: This course is an elective clerkship which introduces hospital pharmacy practice and clinical pharmacy services in various research and teaching hospitals in mainland China. Students will participate in rounding activities, patient case discussions, and disease state management discussions with pharmacy preceptors each week. Specialties involved in the training include cardiology, general internal medicine, and critical care medicine. Students will also be exposed to information regarding licensure requirements and employment opportunities in mainland China.

• Describe the hospital pharmacy distribution and procurement system in mainland China
• Describe the basic set-up and daily operations of a hospital pharmacy
• Outline the roles and responsibilities of a hospital pharmacist
• Be able to interpret/dispense prescriptions and supply medicines in accordance with the legal requirements in the mainland China inpatient and outpatient setting
• Counsel patients and customers on prescription and nonprescription drugs
• Acquire basic knowledge of some disease states in internal medicine
• Differentiate any practice and legal differences between mainland China and local Hong Kong hospital pharmacies
• Analyze a patient case and identify any drug-related problem and be able to formulate a plan to optimize therapy
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to Hospital Pharmacy Clerkship
• Professional Conduct
• Patient Confidentiality
• Pharmacy Law and Ethics
• Dispensing Practice
• Patient Counseling

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Clinical Pharmacy Clerkship: Geriatrics

meetings.instructor: Dr. TAI Bik Wai

courses.description: This elective clerkship is designed to provide training experience to students in geriatric pharmacy practice and patient care within the health system. The clerkship learning strategies include ward round, pharmacy round, in-service staff education, patient counselling, and interaction with different health-care professionals in geriatric medicine. Students will have the opportunity to assess medication regimen for drug-related problems in geriatric illnesses, provide drug information to patients, caregivers and medical staff in geriatric care, and recognize the role of pharmacist in multidisciplinary team in geriatrics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the three-week rotation, the student will be able to:

* Demonstrate an understanding of the clinical presentations of and usual care for common geriatric illnesses
* Appreciate the essential components of a physical examination and selection of treatment modalities, including drug therapy, from physician’s perspective, in geriatric care
* Examine any medication-related problems in geriatric drug regimen review with consideration on efficacy, adverse effects, drug-drug interactions, laboratory data, cost, and local drug use policies
* Develop a working relationship and communicate effectively with the health-care team, including physicians, nurses, and other allied health professionals in geriatric interprofessional care
* Display self-motivation for professional growth as a competent student pharmacist in geriatric pharmacy practice
* Demonstrate the ability to proactively identify opportunities available in the provision of pharmaceutical care to the aging population
courses.course_syllabus:
* Dementia
* Parkinson disease
* Geriatric depression
* Hypertension
* Diabetes
* Dyslipidemia
* Urinary incontinence
* Fall
* Degenerative musculoskeletal conditions
* Pressure-induced skin and soft tissue injuries
* Dysphagia and nutrition problems
* Sarcopenia
* Polypharmacy / Deprescribing

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Pharmacogenomics and Personalized Medicine Clerkship
courses.description: This course is an elective clerkship which introduces the concept of utilizing pharmacogenomics (PG) information and integrating it in clinical decision making. Students will be placed at a DNA biotechnology company, which provides PG information and recommendations on how to personalize treatment and/or monitoring to physicians and patients. Students will have the opportunity to work directly with the chief pharmacist and scientists in the field of Nutrigenomics, Biomedical Science, Bioinformatics etc. Students will carry out literature search/evaluations and/or public education projects.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the three-week rotation, the student will:
• Understand and appreciate the role of a pharmacist in PG and personalized medicine
• Demonstrate a basic understanding of the different polymorphisms in drug metabolism
• Be able to educate the general public on Pharmacogenomics principles and the appropriate indications for clinical PG testing
• Be able to design a patient-specific drug and dosage regimen based on the patient’s PG profile
• Be able to communicate therapy recommendations to the physicians
• Be exposed to the current on-going PG related clinical trials
• Demonstrate ability to self-learn
• Demonstrate ability to collaborate with others
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to the role of pharmacist
• Patient confidentiality
• Literature search and review
• Product research and development
• Education to the general public on PG counseling
• Personalized treatment plan
• Cytochrome isoenzyme polymorphisms
• Common gene mutations (eg. drug transporters, target enzymes, etc.)
• HLA testing for hypersensitivity
courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-term Course and Teaching Evaluation (CTE)

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Drug Information Clerkship
courses.description: The Drug Information Clerkship is a clinical clerkship rotation designed to provide students with practical training to further develop drug information skills. Drug information involves not only the literature evaluation of evidence based information but also drug education and identification of adverse drug events to ensure patient safety. Building upon the knowledge of the different references, students will learn techniques that will enhance their proficiency in information search and critical assessment skills. Verbal and written communication skills are crucial in drug information in order for such information to be disseminated effectively. To emphasize these areas, students are expected to communicate with patients through drug counseling, with the public by conducting educational programs, and with other health care professionals and colleagues during therapeutic use evaluation. Utilizing the School of Pharmacy’s On-Line Drug-Enquiry Platform (AMPOULE), the clerkship exposes students to the many different types of questions from real patients who expect high quality and professional advice.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To develop clinical skills to assess drug information enquiry and perform appropriate analysis.
2. To provide organized, coherent and well thought of response that are specific to the patient’s drug therapy.
3. To obtain sufficient experience in literature retrieval, analysis and dissemination of drug information.
4. To develop skills in scientific literature evaluation and critical assessment of research methodologies and outcomes.
5. To communicate with patients, colleagues and other health care professionals proficiently.
6. To present effectively to the general public through public lecture experiences.
7. To establish competent writing and editing skills pertinent in developing patient education materials and newsletters.
8. To explain the medication systems management and its role in the current health care environment.
9. To identify key elements of database management that could improve medication safety.
10. To establish a systematic manner for proper documentation for adverse drug reaction reporting.
11. To provide drug information response with proper reference citation.
12. To establish strong problem solving skills to understand what the enquirers ask and to provide follow up questions for missing information.
13. To know when to make proper referrals with potential drug information questions that need physician’s attention.
14. To know when and how to report potential adverse drug reaction to the Drug of Office at the Department of Health.
15. To understand the Hong Kong Hospital Authority process of facilitating the analysis of information from all databases within the system and utilize such information in medication-related patient care.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Basic drug information skills and techniques
• Literature evaluation techniques to address drug information questions
• Data collection and achieving skills
• Development of educational tools for public education
• Proper adverse drug reaction handling and reporting
• Introduction of medication systems management
• Legal and ethical aspects of drug information practice
• Professional writing
• Preparation of drug evaluation monograph

meetings.instructor: Professor TO Kin Wah

courses.description: This clerkship course aims to provide short-term pharmacy research experience to final year pharmacy students. Students will be assigned a project, according to individual preference, from various disciplines ((i) Pharmaceutical sciences: e.g., medicinal chemistry, physical pharmacy, pharmacokinetics, pharmacology, pharmacognosy, pharmaceutical analysis; or (ii) Pharmacy practice: e.g., drug use evaluation, pharmacoeconomic analysis, the pharmacists’ impact on patients’ disease outcome).
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students should be able to

* Evaluate literature relevant to a research topic critically
* Master basic research and data analytical skills, e.g., development of appropriate research methodology/protocols, interpretation of literature data, operation of analytical equipment, data analysis using commercially available statistical or curve fitting software, which are relevant to the area of research; and
* Communicate and disseminate research findings effectively to the scientific community and the public.

courses.title: Pharmacokinetics and Pharmacogenetics
courses.description: This course provides students with an understanding of applying pharmacokinetics & pharmacogenetics in pharmacy practice. Principles of Pharmacokinetics, pharmacogenetics and therapeutic monitoring will be discussed. Case examples on specific drugs will be illustrated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the Pharmacokinetics module, students should be able to:
• Apply basic pharmacokinetic concepts in pharmacy practice
• calculate and interpret individual pharmacokinetic parameters
• Individualize drug dosing regimens based on specific organ function, pharmacokinetics parameters and measured drug levels
• Effectively communicate pharmacokinetic concepts and therapy recommendation in clinical pharmacy practice

Upon completion of the Pharmacogenetics module, students should be able to:
• Outline theories of basic genetics and pharmacogenetics
• Summarize and apply clinically available pharmacogenetic tests
courses.course_syllabus:
- Basic and clinical pharmacokinetics

- Therapeutic drug monitoring

- Pharmacogenetics principles and applications

courses.description: This course will provide lectures and practical sessions on the assessment of cost effectiveness of drugs by utilizing various pharmacoeconomics analyses and techniques.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
• Describe and compare the health care system of Hong Kong with that of the major western and Asian countries
• Differentiate between various types of cost-analysis and be able to select the appropriate type of analysis to be used in different scenarios
• Define direct, indirect, intangible, incremental and opportunity costs, and classify them based on the prospective taken
• Collect and calculate the costs of different alternative procedures or therapies
• Design and evaluate a pharmacoeconomics study

courses.description: In contemporary practice, pharmacists are taking a leading role in promoting patient safety and the effective and safe use of medicines. The ultimate goal is to improve individual and public health. This course will expand student’s knowledge on principles and practices of primary care and patient safety. Key public health principles, adverse drug reactions (ADR) monitoring,topics in primary care, and quality assurance measures will be covered in this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this module, students should be able to:
A. Appreciate the key public health concepts for promoting health and preventing diseases through the organized efforts of individuals and society
B. Understand commonly used quality measures in monitoring drug use for a larger population.
C. Explore the role of pharmacists in special topics in primary care focusing on disease management and prevention.
D. Learn the principles of patient safety, including the systematic monitoring of drug safety and the role of pharmacists in ADR reporting and management.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Role of Pharmacists in Public Health
• Quality of care, Risk reduction & Patient safety
• Role of Clinical Pharmacist in ADR reporting
• Hospital accreditation: Key Elements to Evaluate
• Special Topics in Primary Care

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Pharmacotherapy: Pharmaceutical Care in Geriatrics
courses.description: This course aims to teach students drug therapy principles for older adults and common drug related problems encourntered when caring for older adults. Students will participate in the delivery of care and services to elderly patients in various settings.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
• Recognize the influence of aging on drug therapy and the therapeutic adjustment needed
• Predict the response to therapy posed by the elderly in common disease states
• Interpret the physical, laboratory, and diagnostic test results in accordance with age-related changes
• Provide appropriate drug therapy counseling and monitoring for elderly patients
• Analyze the risk and benefit of medication use in the elderly and individualize therapy accordingly
courses.course_syllabus:
• Common chronic diseases in community elderly & Management
• Principle of geriatric care, Geriatric syndrome & management. Pharmacists’ role in nursing home: practice pearls
• Pain management in Elderly and Deprescribing
• Case Illustration: Geriatric syndrome and management; drug treatment for osteoporosis
• Geriatric pharmacy practice service sharing
• Pharmacotherapy in Elderly: Anticoagulation, heart failure and coronary artery disease; Constipation & urinary incontinence; Parkinson’s disease and stroke
• Drug compatibility in tube feeding
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course. Students are welcome to give feedback by filling in the course evaluation form anonymously.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers.

courses.description: This course provides students with in-depth therapeutic knowledge on cardiovascular disorders. Treatment guidelines and considerations in therapy selection will be discussed. Emphasis will be placed on solving therapy-related problems with the knowledge acquired.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
A. Describe the essential knowledge needed for care provision in patients with cardiovascular diseases.
B. Identify relevant patient information needed for therapy assessment.
C. Interpret subjective and objective findings from patient cases.
D. Identify actual and/or potential drug-related problems with therapy.
E. Apply relevant medical and drug information for therapy assessment.
F. Formulate patient specific recommendation and monitoring plan.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Coronary artery disease
• Hypertension
• Dyslipidemia
• Heart failure
• Stroke
• Thromboembolic disorders
• Physician case illustration seminar - cardiovascular diseases
• Cardiology literature update
• Ward round
• Student case presentations

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Clinical Pharmacy Practice Exposure: Internal Medicine (Acute Care)

meetings.instructor: Dr. LEE Chui Ping
Dr. LEE Chui Ping

courses.description: This elective course is designed to provide students with hands on experience in the management of common, acute medical conditions in a hospital setting. Through a combination of ward round, patient case discussion and interaction with different health-care professionals in internal medicine, students will be able to enhance their clinical reasoning skills, expand their knowledge of pharmacotherapy in acute internal medicine, and gain practical experience necessary to optimize medication therapy for patients with acute internal medicine conditions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the one-week exposure, the student will be able to:
• Examine medication-related problems in drug regimen review considering efficacy, safety and cost in acute care, inpatient setting
• Design safe and effective patient-centered therapeutic regimens and monitoring plans
• Develop a working relationship and communicate effectively with the health-care team, including physicians, nurses, and other allied health professionals in interprofessional care
courses.course_syllabus:
• Endocrine disorders
• Acute cardiovascular disorders or exacerbations
• Infections
• Complication of acute or chronic kidney disorders
• Respiratory distress
• Medication Reconciliation
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students will be encouraged to provide any suggestions for learning enhancement for the teacher’s consideration. Course evaluation will be also be done at the end of the course. Students are welcome to give feedback by filling in the course evaluation form anonymously.
courses.required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers.
courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers.

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Clinical Pharmacy Practice Exposure: Internal Medicine (Ambulatory Care)

meetings.instructor: Dr. LEE Chui Ping
Dr. LEE Chui Ping

courses.description: This elective course is designed to provide students with hands on experience in the management of common, chronic medical conditions in ambulatory care setting. Through participation in pharmacist clinic visits, patient case discussion, patient counselling, and interaction with different health-care professionals, students will be able to enhance their clinical reasoning skills, expand their knowledge of pharmacotherapy seen in ambulatory care, and gain practical experience necessary to optimize medication therapy for patients with chronic internal medicine conditions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the one-week exposure, the student will be able to:
• Examine medication-related problems in drug regimen review considering efficacy, safety and cost in ambulatory care setting
• Facilitate the delivery of safe and effective patient-centered therapeutic regimens and monitoring plans
• Develop a working relationship and communicate effectively with the health-care team, including physicians, nurses, and other allied health professionals in interprofessional care
courses.course_syllabus:
• Medication Management
• Anticoagulation
• Endocrine
• Rheumatology
• Medication Reconciliation
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students will be encouraged to provide any suggestions for learning enhancement for the teacher’s consideration. Course evaluation will be also be done at the end of the course. Students are welcome to give feedback by filling in the course evaluation form anonymously.

courses.subject: PHAR
courses.title: Graduation Project II

meetings.location: Lee Shau Kee Archi Bldg G04
meetings.instructor:
Dr. LEE Chui Ping, 
Dr. TAI Bik Wai, 
Dr. YUEN Siu Hong Johnny, 
Dr. ZHOU Keary Rui, 
Professor CHEUNG Yin Ting, 
Professor LAM Tai Ning, 
Professor YOU Hoi Sze Joyce

courses.description: This course consists of independent and teamwork with supervision. Students are required to implement a predetermined practice-based project of interest in their work settings. The project should demonstrate pharmacists' impact on patient care, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management. Students are expected to be involved in project implementation, outcome measurement, result analysis, report writing and presentation. Pre-requisite: PHAR5824.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Clinical Pharmacy; Prerequisite: PHAR5824
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the project, students should be able to
• Implement a practice-based project that can demonstrate pharmacist’s impact on patient care, teaching, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management
• Demonstrate application of knowledge and motivation to learn
• Identify potential obstacles in conducting a project and formulate strategies to solve them accordingly
• Non-verbally and verbally communicate effectively as demonstrated by written reports and oral presentation of project
• Be flexible and adaptive to unforeseen circumstances and strive to take alternative approaches in different situations
• Demonstrate ability in working as a team and good interpersonal skills
• Demonstrate good time-management skills and logical organization of tasks
• Develop working knowledge on computer software commonly used for data analysis
courses.course_syllabus:
• Process of conducting a practice-based project that can demonstrate pharmacist’s impact on patient care, teaching, pharmaceutical research and development or administrative management
• potential obstacles in conducting a project and formulate strategies to solve them accordingly
• Working knowledge on computer software commonly used for data analysis
courses.feedback_evaluation: Course evaluation will be done at the end of the course. Students are welcome to give feedback by filling in the course evaluation form anonymously.

courses.recommended_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by course teachers.

courses.description: To present a seminar summarising research work performed in the previous term / year.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course enables students to:
• Disseminate their research proposal and findings effectively, and demonstrate the abilities to justify all the decisions involved in the study design, experimental procedures, results interpretation and discussions.
• Critically discuss their own and others’ research problems and the significance to the research in pharmaceutical sciences and pharmacy practice.
• Understand the applications of different research methodologies as scientific tools to address various clinical and research questions in pharmaceutical sciences and pharmacy practice.
• Evaluate and critique issues in research methods, results analyses and discussions from research presentations.
• Engage constructively in the scholarly discussion of research presentations.
courses.course_syllabus: Under the guidance of supervisors, students prepare to present their research progress at the graduate seminar.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Feedback could be given duriing student-teacher meetings and graduate panel meeting. Feedback is also documented on CUSIS online study plan and progress report system.
